posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
Partially inspired by some discussion on the REV product release thread , I’ve designed and assembled a prototype locking system for the MAXPlanetary. This is a V2 of the design, and I’m sure there are many more iterations to come as we test it further. Right now, I’ve only designed a clockwise ratchet, but I plan to design a counter-clockwise ratchet and a break. This is also designed to be as simple to make as possible, and very easy to just slap onto an existing mechanism. This adds ~1" in height and ~0.5" in width, which in my opinion packages really nicely! We might try and run this at a few offseasons for a climb with our elevator, so more testing coming soon! Also, I want to test the max load it can handle. I’ll do that once I get access to the shop.- Main Assembly(18) 3296×2547 534 KB Here’s a quick demo of it working:

Main Assembly(18) 3296×2547 534 KB

Main Assembly(18) 3296×2547 534 KB

It is an attachment that goes between the input stage of a MAXPlanetary and the motor powering the MAXPlanetary. A servo and spring linkage activate the ratchet, deciding whether it is on or off. Since it is located before the input stage, it is 1:1 to the NEO and doesn’t need to be very strong to stop the motor from being back-driven.

This can have a ton of possible uses, and I’m excited to see what people think of! However, the main use case is to put it on a climber. Many endgames in FRC require a robot to stay off the ground for a number of seconds, and when your climber backdrives you can loose climb points. In the past,the main way to prevent this was gear really high so the friction stops it from backdriving. However, a climber that is geared really high is also really slow. So, by using this you can have a fast climber that also doesn’t backdrive.

Here’s a youtube video that gives a general overview of the design, and assembly instructions:

CAD BOM

If 111 is able to, this attachment should allow us to climb and stay climbed with our elevator once we add hooks. I’m looking forward to exploring this in the offseason. Example of how it would look on our lift: 24W4000 - Lift Feed(3) 3296×2547 1.8 MB

24W4000 - Lift Feed(3) 3296×2547 1.8 MB

24W4000 - Lift Feed(3) 3296×2547 1.8 MB

I’m looking forward to hearing questions, comments, and suggestions!

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: Very cool, and very useful!  Let us know how it goes if you end up using it for off season events.

posts.name: Unnatural Twilight
posts.cooked:
Could this be designed to replace the input stage?

That would remove the depth penalty of adding this but it is an excellent design regardless.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Design Lead & Master of Sketchy Solutions

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
So this is really interesting. If I were to make that, the packaging challenge sounds fun.

Some obstacles to that- You’d need to drill a shaft clearance hole into the 1/2" hex MAXPlanetary input adapter, which would make fabricating this in season at least a bit tougher. Without doing that, you are stuck with the current dimensions as the NEO can’t go down any farther. If I did that, I could honestly just make the entire thing thinner without even removing the input stage. image 1683×1186 131 KB

image 1683×1186 131 KB

image 1683×1186 131 KB

Also, I’d need to have a 3D printed part support the motor and the pawl with two bolts. I’m not sure if I could design it to be strong enough.

And the last thing, I’d have to design it again, which would take a lot of time. I want to make sure I perfect this design first, I think. Especially since the length of the MAXPlanetary doesn’t really matter for the packaging of them (In most applications).

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: I’d be curious if you could add a limit switch to signal the motor controller to not spin against the ratchet.

posts.name: Garrison
posts.cooked: Would replacing the metal hex 3D print insert with an 8mm shaft (or spline for krakens) pinion help? Seems like this might fix the shaft clearance issue.

posts.name: Pat Mattin
posts.cooked:
The servo already has a potentiometer built in for position control. A software lockout should be as simple as monitoring the position of the servo. A limit switch would likely be redundant.

To the main topic, really cool design! Definitely interested in how it performs on a robot.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: Well technically servos don’t provide any feedback. They just read the pwm from the Rio. Sure you can still program that in, but actual feedback that the servo is still alive is important at least in my opinion

posts.name: Taiga
posts.cooked:
It looks like a micro servo, it acts like a micro servo, but it's more than just a micro servo! We got a factory to custom-make these quality metal-geared 'micro' sized hobby  ...

Price: $14.95 USD

Something like this, perhaps? Not quite a limit switch, but still gives active positional feedback (that could connect into a SPARK MAX/Flex data port and send signals to the RIO)

posts.name: Travis Norris
posts.cooked:
This is awesome! I love that the ratchet teeth are clocked to the hex insert teeth to avoid any weak points.

Eliot Dunn:

plan to design a counter-clockwise ratchet and a break.

It would be great if the different versions were easily identifiable from the outside. Maybe text or a symbol in the linkage arm?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Head Coach - FRC 2423 | NEMC Planning Committee

posts.name: Unnatural Twilight
posts.cooked: That all makes sense. I wasn’t really considering in season fabrication time and your right about it being a tight fit. I’m not sure I’d want a 3d print holding up a climb motor either.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Design Lead & Master of Sketchy Solutions

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
I think if the system doesn’t have enough reliability that I can trust the servo to be on or off when I command it to be on or off, I shouldn’t be running the system at all. Since a climb (the most common use case of this) would hurt the robot a lot if it fell off, I want this to be extremely reliable. I think if a limit switch is needed, I already failed in the design of the system.

However, if you do want some feedback from the system, the analog feedback micro servo that taiga linked would be a drop-in solution to this.

Additionally, adding a limit switch would add additional points of failure and complexity, and also raise the BOM, which right now is ~25 usd excluding printed parts per unit.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
I think that would help a lot. I need to look into what the thinnest gears I could use for an insert are, maybe MAXSwerve pinions would work I also need to check how a key interfaces with this. I think I got too caught up in using a ttb hex insert when I was originally brainstorming the design.

I’ll make a branch of the design sometime and try out this idea.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: Interesting design. I’m a bit curious to know if it would release under load or not, given the servo would be pushing against what appears to be nothing but a spring. While I understand the need for a spring in the mechanism in order for it to ratchet, I feel like there’s probably more durable options than this particular approach.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: This will not release under load.  You would need to write a bit of code to tell it “retract the pawl” and then move forward just a touch to unload.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
With a machined part you could shrink/press/loctite/setscrew it onto the OD of a standard MAXPlanetary input adapter.

Printed parts would be much more difficult to get enough torque transmitting capacity.  You might be able to cross pin it off center, but it would be fiddly.  You don’t want to cross into the shaft hole, especially with the splined ones.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
cbale2000:

I’m a bit curious to know if it would release under load or not

This does release under load, at least when tested with me manually giving the load (turning the input adapter by hand). It’s because of the pawl’s design, it doesn’t really lock. The pawl’s interface with the ratchet is an arc with a centerpoint of the pivot rather than a straight line, so the pawl doesn’t have to push the ratchet at all. This may be worse for durability, but I think it should be fine. If it ends up being a failure point when testing, I’ll change it.

cbale2000:

given the servo would be pushing against what appears to be nothing but a spring.

While it is just a spring, the force required for this is counterintuivley small. It appears that the spring is more than strong enough for the job, at least when testing it using my hands. I’ll have to wait until the shop is open for me to more thouroughly test it. If it’s a problem I’ll look into other solutions. This video is a close-up of the acutation with the spring:

Weldingrod1:

With a machined part you could shrink/press/loctite/setscrew it onto the OD of a standard MAXPlanetary input adapter.

While I’m sure this would work, I’d prefer to keep the BOM down and make it as simple as possible for every team to implement this onto their robot. Many teams do not have access to machining tools, and a lot do have acess to a 3D printer. Additionally, for this to be on your robot you need to fabricate it in season so this should be as easy for us to make as possible.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Working on a Kraken-flavored version with a spline in the pawl…

posts.cooked: Versioned the document because I needed more clearance in the CCW pawl. 111 will be testing this for our climb this year.

accepted_answer.excerpt: We really struggled with the tiny tension spring on this design. So we modified it to use an elastic band to load the pawl instead. We mounted it this evening and can confirm it works well! @Eliot [PXL_20250310_211930949.MP] [image-3]
